required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Food Additives Effects on EEG Profiles in College Students With ADHD
clinical_study.official_title: Food Additives Effects on EEG Profiles in College Students With ADHD

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to examine the effects of food additives on college students with ADHD. This study could potentially answer an important question which still remains unanswered as to whether certain food additives may be able to cause cognitive and electrical activity changes in college students with and without ADHD. In this context, food additives will be artificial food coloring.

detailed_description.textblock: Consent will be obtained at the first visit. Baseline data will be collected on the participants, including height, weight, computerized cognitive functioning, and an EEG recording. Participants will also be taught how to keep a detailed food and symptom diary over the following week. One week later, the participant will return to the lab and turn in the food/symptom diary. All ADHD participants and a subgroup of controls (called extended controls or EC) will be trained on how to follow the dietary intervention. Detailed information on the diet will be given, including food additives to avoid, healthy foods which should be eaten, and shopping tips. For the next two weeks, the participant will follow the dietary intervention at home with access to Dr. Holton to answer any questions. The participant will return to the lab after following the diet for two weeks and assessments (cognitive testing, and EEG) will be completed again along information on dietary compliance will be collected. The third meeting will also mark the beginning of the first challenge period. For the challenges, the participant will consume chocolate cookies every Monday, Tuesday, and Wednesday for two weeks. The cookies may or may not contain artificial food coloring depending on the week. Every Wednesday repeat testing will be completed after the cookies are consumed. The participant will be asked not to take ADHD medication on testing days. After two weeks of challenges the study will be completed. The participant will receive information on their performance and on the study results overall.

study_design_info.intervention_model_description: All ADHD participants and a subgroup of control participants will be exposed to all challenge mixtures (artificial food coloring/placebo, placebo/artificial food coloring) with adequate washout periods between exposures.
study_design_info.masking_description: The investigators and the participants will be masked as to contents of the chocolate cookies provided during the challenge periods. One research assistant will be unblinded and will not have contact with the participants.

primary_outcome.measure: Mean Power (EEG) During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected after three days exposure to AFC (on third day) and after three day exposure to placebo (on third day)
primary_outcome.description: Electroencephalography (EEG) is an objective measure of brainwave activity that non-invasively records the electrocortical activity emitted from neuronal postsynaptic outputs using small electrodes placed on the head. Quantitative EEG uses techniques to transform electrocortical voltage amplitudes into frequency bands to reflect mental processes in periodicities instead of raw values. These frequency bands can then be compared before/after treatment and/or between groups to better understand how treatment impacts the brain. Resting-state EEG was collected with eyes-closed, but awake, for four minutes Frequency bands assessed: delta 1-4Hz, theta 4-7Hz, alpha 8-13Hz, beta 13-30Hz, gamma 30-50Hz Each frequency band was assessed using: mean power (microvolts^2 of a frequency band divided by the length of the frequency band) a

primary_outcome.measure: Relative Power (EEG) During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected after three days exposure to AFC (on third day) and after three day exposure to placebo (on third day)
primary_outcome.description: Electroencephalography (EEG) is an objective measure of brainwave activity that non-invasively records the electrocortical activity emitted from neuronal postsynaptic outputs using small electrodes placed on the head. Quantitative EEG uses techniques to transform electrocortical voltage amplitudes into frequency bands to reflect mental processes in periodicities instead of raw values. These frequency bands can then be compared before/after treatment and/or between groups to better understand how treatment impacts the brain. Resting-state EEG was collected with eyes-closed, but awake, for four minutes Frequency bands assessed: delta 1-4Hz, theta 4-7Hz, alpha 8-13Hz, beta 13-30Hz, gamma 30-50Hz Each frequency band was assessed using: relative power (sum of microvolts^2 of a frequency band divided by total power to get a percent)

primary_outcome.measure: ADHD Symptoms During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
primary_outcome.time_frame: Collected after three days exposure to AFC (on third day) and after three day exposure to placebo (on third day)
primary_outcome.description: Name: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale-V1.1 Construct: Self-report checklist of adult ADHD symptoms to screen for possibility of ADHD. It is not meant to be diagnostic. According to the documentation, "The questions in the ASRS v1.1 are consistent with DSM-IV criteria and address the manifestations of ADHD symptoms in adults." Total Range: 0-72 points - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of adult ADHD symptoms Sub-scores: Inattentive: sum of number/frequency of nine questions (taken from full ASRS questionnaire) related to inattention Range: 0-36 - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of inattention symptoms Hyperactive: sum of number/frequency of nine questions (taken from full ASRS questionnaire) related to hyperactivity Range: 0-36 - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of hyperactivity symptoms

arm_group.arm_group_label: ADHD- Artificial food coloring, then placebo
arm_group.description: Participants first received 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday). After a 4-day washout period, they then received placebo of chocolate cookies and consumed them over three days.

arm_group.arm_group_label: ADHD - Placebo, then artificial food coloring
arm_group.description: Participants first received placebo of chocolate cookies and consumed them over three days. After a 4-day washout period, they then received 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday).

arm_group.arm_group_label: Controls- Artificial food coloring, then placebo
arm_group.description: Participants first received 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday). After a 4-day washout period, they then received placebo of chocolate cookies and consumed them over three days.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Controls - Placebo, then artificial food coloring
arm_group.description: Participants first received placebo of chocolate cookies and consumed them over three days. After a 4-day washout period, they then received 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday).

intervention.arm_group_label: ADHD - Placebo, then artificial food coloring
ADHD- Artificial food coloring, then placebo

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Generally good health
- 18-24 years old
- Currently attending college
- Physician's diagnosis of ADHD (unless control participant)
- Stable medication dose and frequency for 3 months before the study
- Willing to suspend ADHD medication administration on testing day and the day after testing
Exclusion Criteria:
- Presence of comorbid psychiatric condition other than comorbid depression or anxiety
- Autism
- Severe asthma requiring past hospitalization
- Seizure disorder

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants with ADHD and neuro-typical controls were recruited from Jan. 2018 until Oct. 2018 at a Mid-Atlantic University.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Two-week AFC-free diet to standardize intake before randomization to challenge with AFC relative to placebo. Washout period of 4 days between challenge with AFC and placebo.

group.title: ADHD- Artificial Food Coloring Challenge First, Then Placebo
group.description: A high consumer child dose totaling of 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) will be mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday). The chocolate will mask the food coloring. The next week they will received placebo cookies for three days. Artificial Food Coloring: Artificial Food Coloring (AFC)

group.title: ADHD- Placebo Challenge First, Then Artificial Food Coloring
group.description: The participants will consume chocolate cookies with no food coloring for three days. The next week a high consumer dose totaling of 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) will be mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday).

group.title: Control - Artificial Food Coloring First, Then Placebo
group.description: A high consumer child dose totaling of 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) will be mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday). The chocolate will mask the food coloring. The next week they will received placebo cookies for three days.

group.title: Control - Placebo First, Then Artificial Food Coloring
group.description: The participants will consume chocolate cookies with no food coloring for three days. The next week a high consumer dose totaling of 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) will be mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday).

baseline.population: The ADHD group is college students diagnosed with ADHD and the control group is college students not diagnosed with ADHD. All ADHD participants (except for one drop out before randomization) and 11 controls participants moved on the the randomized placebo-controlled crossover challenge portion of the study.

group.title: ADHD Group
group.description: College students diagnosed with ADHD.

group.title: Control Group
group.description: College students not diagnosed with ADHD

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

category.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

measure.title: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale (ASRS)
measure.description: Name: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale-V1.1 Construct: Self-report checklist of adult ADHD symptoms to screen for possibility of ADHD. It is not meant to be diagnostic. According to the documentation, "The questions in the ASRS v1.1 are consistent with DSM-IV criteria and address the manifestations of ADHD symptoms in adults." Total Range: 0-72 points - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of adult ADHD symptoms

measure.title: Diagnoses
measure.description: This variable included medical and psychological diagnoses. The most commonly reported diagnoses were anxiety and depression.

outcome.title: Mean Power (EEG) During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
outcome.description: Electroencephalography (EEG) is an objective measure of brainwave activity that non-invasively records the electrocortical activity emitted from neuronal postsynaptic outputs using small electrodes placed on the head. Quantitative EEG uses techniques to transform electrocortical voltage amplitudes into frequency bands to reflect mental processes in periodicities instead of raw values. These frequency bands can then be compared before/after treatment and/or between groups to better understand how treatment impacts the brain. Resting-state EEG was collected with eyes-closed, but awake, for four minutes Frequency bands assessed: delta 1-4Hz, theta 4-7Hz, alpha 8-13Hz, beta 13-30Hz, gamma 30-50Hz Each frequency band was assessed using: mean power (microvolts^2 of a frequency band divided by the length of the frequency band) a
outcome.time_frame: Collected after three days exposure to AFC (on third day) and after three day exposure to placebo (on third day)
outcome.population: Models run for ADHD and control groups, separately.

group.title: ADHD- Artificial Food Coloring
group.description: 225 mg AFC over three days received either the first or second week.

group.title: ADHD- Placebo
group.description: Placebo cookies over three days received either the first for second week.

group.title: Control - Artificial Food Coloring
group.description: 225 mg AFC over three days received either the first or second week.

group.title: Control - Placebo
group.description: Placebo cookies over three days received either the first or second week.

measure.title: Mean Power (EEG) During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
measure.description: Electroencephalography (EEG) is an objective measure of brainwave activity that non-invasively records the electrocortical activity emitted from neuronal postsynaptic outputs using small electrodes placed on the head. Quantitative EEG uses techniques to transform electrocortical voltage amplitudes into frequency bands to reflect mental processes in periodicities instead of raw values. These frequency bands can then be compared before/after treatment and/or between groups to better understand how treatment impacts the brain. Resting-state EEG was collected with eyes-closed, but awake, for four minutes Frequency bands assessed: delta 1-4Hz, theta 4-7Hz, alpha 8-13Hz, beta 13-30Hz, gamma 30-50Hz Each frequency band was assessed using: mean power (microvolts^2 of a frequency band divided by the length of the frequency band) a
measure.population: Models run for ADHD and control groups, separately.

analysis.groups_desc: Difference in Delta Power in ADHD group with and without exposure to AFC. General linear model assessed the impact of treatment (AFC v. placebo) on each EEG frequency band, taking into account order of materials. Dependent variable = Treatment (EEG power during AFC, EEG power during placebo); independent variable = order (AFC/placebo, placebo/AFC) This is a pilot study, thus a power calculation was not done and it was not power to correct for multiple comparisons.
analysis.p_value_desc: Significance level </= 0.05. This was chosen due to the small sample size. The p-value is not adjusted for multiple comparisons as this was a pilot study and a power analysis for sample size was not conducted.

analysis.groups_desc: Difference in Theta Power in ADHD group with and without exposure to AFC. outcome.title: Relative Power (EEG) During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
outcome.description: Electroencephalography (EEG) is an objective measure of brainwave activity that non-invasively records the electrocortical activity emitted from neuronal postsynaptic outputs using small electrodes placed on the head. Quantitative EEG uses techniques to transform electrocortical voltage amplitudes into frequency bands to reflect mental processes in periodicities instead of raw values. These frequency bands can then be compared before/after treatment and/or between groups to better understand how treatment impacts the brain. Resting-state EEG was collected with eyes-closed, but awake, for four minutes Frequency bands assessed: delta 1-4Hz, theta 4-7Hz, alpha 8-13Hz, beta 13-30Hz, gamma 30-50Hz Each frequency band was assessed using: relative power (sum of microvolts^2 of a frequency band divided by total power to get a percent)
outcome.time_frame: Collected after three days exposure to AFC (on third day) and after three day exposure to placebo (on third day)
outcome.population: Models run for ADHD and control groups, separately.

These frequency bands can then be compared before/after treatment and/or between groups to better understand how treatment impacts the brain. Resting-state EEG was collected with eyes-closed, but awake, for four minutes Frequency bands assessed: delta 1-4Hz, theta 4-7Hz, alpha 8-13Hz, beta 13-30Hz, gamma 30-50Hz Each frequency band was assessed using: relative power (sum of microvolts^2 of a frequency band divided by total power to get a percent)

outcome.title: ADHD Symptoms During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
outcome.description: Name: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale-V1.1 Construct: Self-report checklist of adult ADHD symptoms to screen for possibility of ADHD. It is not meant to be diagnostic. According to the documentation, "The questions in the ASRS v1.1 are consistent with DSM-IV criteria and address the manifestations of ADHD symptoms in adults." Total Range: 0-72 points - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of adult ADHD symptoms Sub-scores: Inattentive: sum of number/frequency of nine questions (taken from full ASRS questionnaire) related to inattention Range: 0-36 - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of inattention symptoms Hyperactive: sum of number/frequency of nine questions (taken from full ASRS questionnaire) related to hyperactivity Range: 0-36 - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of hyperactivity symptoms
outcome.time_frame: Collected after three days exposure to AFC (on third day) and after three day exposure to placebo (on third day)
outcome.population: Models run for ADHD and control groups, separately.

group.title: ADHD- Artificial Food Coloring
group.description: 225 mg of mixed AFC over three days received either the first or second week.

group.title: ADHD - Placebo Challenge
group.description: Placebo cookies over three days received either the first or second week.

group.title: Control - Artificial Food Coloring
group.description: 225 mg of mixed AFC over three days received either the first or second week.

group.title: Control - Placebo
group.description: Placebo cookies over three days received either the first or second week.

measure.title: ADHD Symptoms During AFC and Placebo Challenge in ADHD and Control Groups
measure.description: Name: Adult ADHD Self-Report Scale-V1.1 Construct: Self-report checklist of adult ADHD symptoms to screen for possibility of ADHD. It is not meant to be diagnostic. According to the documentation, "The questions in the ASRS v1.1 are consistent with DSM-IV criteria and address the manifestations of ADHD symptoms in adults." Total Range: 0-72 points - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of adult ADHD symptoms Sub-scores: Inattentive: sum of number/frequency of nine questions (taken from full ASRS questionnaire) related to inattention Range: 0-36 - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of inattention symptoms Hyperactive: sum of number/frequency of nine questions (taken from full ASRS questionnaire) related to hyperactivity Range: 0-36 - higher score indicates more and/or higher frequency of hyperactivity symptoms
measure.population: Models run for ADHD and control groups, separately.

analysis.groups_desc: Difference in inattentive ASRS in ADHD group with/without exposure to AFC. General linear model assessed the impact of treatment (AFC v. placebo) on each EEG frequency band, taking into account order of materials. Dependent variable = Treatment (inattentive ASRS score during AFC, inattentive ASRS score during placebo); independent variable = order (AFC/placebo, placebo/AFC) This is a pilot study, thus a power calculation was not done and it was not power to correct for multiple comparisons.
analysis.p_value_desc: Significance level </= 0.05. This was chosen due to the small sample size. The p-value is not adjusted for multiple comparisons as this was a pilot study and a power analysis for sample size was not conducted.

analysis.groups_desc: Difference in hyperactive ASRS in ADHD group with/without exposure to AFC. General linear model assessed the impact of treatment (AFC v. placebo) on each EEG frequency band, taking into account order of materials. Dependent variable = Treatment (hyperactive ASRS score during AFC, hyperactive ASRS score during placebo); independent variable = order (AFC/placebo, placebo/AFC) This is a pilot study, thus a power calculation was not done and it was not power to correct for multiple comparisons.
analysis.p_value_desc: Significance level </= 0.05. This was chosen due to the small sample size. The p-value is not adjusted for multiple comparisons as this was a pilot study and a power analysis for sample size was not conducted.

analysis.groups_desc: Difference in total ASRS in ADHD group with/without exposure to AFC. General linear model assessed the impact of treatment (AFC v. placebo) on each EEG frequency band, taking into account order of materials. Dependent variable = Treatment (total ASRS score during AFC, total ASRS score during placebo); independent variable = order (AFC/placebo, placebo/AFC) This is a pilot study, thus a power calculation was not done and it was not power to correct for multiple comparisons.
analysis.p_value_desc: Significance level </= 0.05. This was chosen due to the small sample size. The p-value is not adjusted for multiple comparisons as this was a pilot study and a power analysis for sample size was not conducted.

analysis.groups_desc: inattentive ASRS in control group with/without exposure to AFC. General linear model assessed the impact of treatment (AFC v. placebo) on each EEG frequency band, taking into account order of materials. Dependent variable = Treatment (inattentive ASRS score during AFC, inattentive ASRS score during placebo); independent variable = order (AFC/placebo, placebo/AFC) This is a pilot study, thus a power calculation was not done and it was not power to correct for multiple comparisons.
analysis.p_value_desc: Significance level </= 0.05. This was chosen due to the small sample size. The p-value is not adjusted for multiple comparisons as this was a pilot study and a power analysis for sample size was not conducted.

analysis.groups_desc: Hyperactive ASRS in control group with/without exposure to AFC. General linear model assessed the impact of treatment (AFC v. placebo) on each EEG frequency band, taking into account order of materials. Dependent variable = Treatment (hyperactive ASRS score during AFC, hyperactive ASRS score during placebo); independent variable = order (AFC/placebo, placebo/AFC) This is a pilot study, thus a power calculation was not done and it was not power to correct for multiple comparisons.
analysis.p_value_desc: Significance level </= 0.05. This was chosen due to the small sample size. The p-value is not adjusted for multiple comparisons as this was a pilot study and a power analysis for sample size was not conducted.

analysis.groups_desc: Difference in total ASRS in control group with/without exposure to AFC. General linear model assessed the impact of treatment (AFC v. placebo) on each EEG frequency band, taking into account order of materials. Dependent variable = Treatment (total ASRS score during AFC, total ASRS score during placebo); independent variable = order (AFC/placebo, placebo/AFC) This is a pilot study, thus a power calculation was not done and it was not power to correct for multiple comparisons.
analysis.p_value_desc: Significance level </= 0.05. This was chosen due to the small sample size. The p-value is not adjusted for multiple comparisons as this was a pilot study and a power analysis for sample size was not conducted.

reported_events.desc: Participants were asked upon each visit how they were feeling and if they had any negative symptoms to report.

group.title: Artificial Food Coloring Challenge
group.description: ADHD and control participants combined. A high consumer child dose totaling of 225 mg of the six most common artificial food colors (Red 40, Red 3, Yellow 5, Yellow 6, Blue 1, and Blue 2) will be mixed in chocolate cookies and consumed consecutively over three days (Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday).

group.title: Placebo Challenge
group.description: ADHD and control participants, combined. The participants will consume chocolate cookies with no food coloring for three days.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: This pilot study had a small sample size, and was not powered to correct for multiple comparisons. The control group had imperfect randomization of challenge materials (AFC/placebo=3, placebo/AFC=8). Dietary compliance was only measured once.
